Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
Section (1) An agency shall only place a child with an adult who is legally
Description related to the child, is a legal custodian, or in a licensed foster
home, except as permitted in R 400.12709.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Children were not placed in legal placement.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via email on March 17, 2023.
Complainant reported she did not have any additional information
to add.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via Teams on
March 22, 2023. CA stated it was her impression all four youth
were initially placed with Placement 2, however it was requested
the three older youth be moved and they were placed with
Placement 1. Placement 1 was somewhat familiar with the
children as they had stayed in the home under a safety plan prior
to a petition being filed and their parents had done odd jobs at
their house. CA stated at the adjourned preliminary hearing on
July 28, 2022, the court was made aware of the fictive kin
placement and instructed foster care to locate other placements
as the court had not approved a fictive kin placement. The agency
immediately filed an appeal following the hearing and the decision
was reversed and the court approved the fictive kin placement on
August 10, 2022. CA stated the initial DHS 5770 did not include
all of the information that supported the fictive kin placement and
Foster Care Worker (FCW) had not been updated with that
information. Once it was presented to the Judge the court agreed
to approve placement.
Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
Teams on March 29, 2023. FC supervisor stated she received a
notification that a petition had been filed regarding Youth A, Youth
B, Youth C and Youth D. Typically within a week there is a
transfer meeting where details of the case are discussed. She
stated upon conducting the first visit with the children there were
concerns regarding Placement 1 and Placement 2 fictive kin
relationship. FC supervisor stated the information conveyed to
foster care staff by Placement 1 and Placement 2 was different
than the information conveyed to protective services staff. Based
on the information received, FC supervisor and FCW did not
believe they met the definition of fictive kin as Placement 1 has
reported they had not met any of the youth prior to them being
placed in their home. FC supervisor stated at the time of
placement she and FCW were told the placements were
temporary and the placement unit was actively looking for other
placement options. FC supervisor stated a TDM was held and the
concerns regarding placements were discussed including the
issue the court had not ordered the fictive kin placement. She
stated the court brought up placement at the adjourned
2

preliminary hearing and was upset when it was discovered Youth
A, Youth B, Youth C and Youth D were in fictive kin placements
without prior approval from the court. The referee then verbally
ordered the youth to be moved to appropriate placements.
Following the hearing, prior to an order being issued, the county
office appealed the order to move all of the youth. FC supervisor
stated the appeal was granted and the court approved the fictive
kin placements.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via Teams on
March 29, 2023. FCW stated at the time the foster care case
opened she was told that Youth A, Youth B, Youth C and Youth D
were in placements with “sort of fictive kin”. It was reported to
FCW that the initial placements were temporary, and the
placement unit was working to identify a long-term placement.
FCW stated she attended the adjourned preliminary hearing and
was asked by the referee about the current placement. When
FCW explained the placement was with fictive kin the referee
became upset and explained the court had not granted approval
for the fictive kin placement.
Documents Reviewed:
 6/14/2022-9/8/2022 CPS closing USP. Closing
recommendations state the children were placed in fictive
kin placements.
 Change of placement TDM held on 7/12/2022 to discuss
fictive kin placement that has not been approved by the
court and the families do not fit the definition of fictive kin.
Recommended the children remain in current placements
until other placements are located.
 7/11/2022 fictive kin safety screen. Signed by Director on
8/12/2022 and uploaded in MISACWIS on 3/17/2023.
Checklist notes once Director approval is obtained, a court
order for Fictive Kin placement is required prior to
placement.
 7/28/2022 court order. Order states the court was informed
today the children were in a fictive kin placement without
court approval nor order. None of the children had a
relationship nor knew of placement prior to CPS placing
them there. FCW testified she had minor concerns
regarding placement due to insufficient income for one of
two fictive kin and no bedding/bedrooms for two children.
Court denies request today for fictive kin placement.
 8/10/2022 court order. Order states fictive kin placement is
allowed by the court.
3

Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance as the youth were placed
in fictive kin placements on 6/24/2022 and did not receive
approval from the court to do so until 8/10/2022.
Conclusion Violation Established

sir_summary.summary: The Wayne County DHHS placed four children in fictive kin homes without required court approval, violating placement rules. The court discovered the unauthorized placements during a hearing, leading to an initial order to remove the children, which the agency appealed and later obtained retroactive approval. The agency's failure to secure prior court authorization and its internal miscommunication regarding the placements' legitimacy constituted a clear violation of procedure, with primary culpability lying with the agency for not following proper approval protocols.
